messages: 53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:15): ugh, gcc warnings irritate me with their vagueness.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:15): testing.c:9: warning: passing argument 1 of 'foo' from incompatible pointer
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:16): "testing.c", line 9: warning: argument #1 is incompatible with prototype:
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:16): prototype: pointer to pointer to const char : "testing.c", line 3
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:16): argument : pointer to pointer to char
fdabeed2de84e59e3564b3318a8768a6 (05:24): to be fair, g++ is better about that
fdabeed2de84e59e3564b3318a8768a6 (05:24): not that it really helps you necessarily
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:28): delewis: re: opening Studio: if you find out, let us know, will you?
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:29): the argument I've heard is that there wouldn't be a lot of interest in improving it
92a2971947f98559b55851639c206ff3 (05:29): Is studio netbeans-based now?
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:29): which is probably true; there's not really much value there

6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:30): wesolows: if the compiler team open sourced Studio, someone would be nuts enough to glue EDG's frontend to it, which would be a huge improvement especially in C++
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:30): one hears rumours, but since the notion of making a compiler based on a Java IDE doesn't make any logical sense, it's impossible to know
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:31): phukq: Well, looking at gccfss, that's probably possible without source
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:31): phukq: not that source wouldn't be helpful

6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:31): jbalint: most of the time, when Studio craps out (and dumps core) the assertions point to translation units ending either in *.c or *.cc, which leads me to believe that it's written in a combination of these two
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:32): wesolows: yah but EDG's front end is really really nice. and Studio's backend is really nice. so this would be a nice combo IMHO
92a2971947f98559b55851639c206ff3 (05:32): I haven't any of the newer ones. Does it look like netbeans?
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:32): phukq: my point was that if you can glue gcc's front end to it, there's probably enough information there to glue some other front end on instead
10bfbd86652c66666f8f32ef19ea8469 (05:38): should the brandz bfu's be applied straight onto a std solaris express install?
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (05:39): phukq: for what it's worth by the way, I wasn't intentionally trying to provoke anyone.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (05:39): (I couldn't tell if you were serious or not, earlier)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:39): richlowe: i was not being serious (i hardly ever am and when i am it's not ambiguous :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:40): richlowe: on the other hand, i personally look forward to 483 more flamewar posts about GPL vs. CDDL because they are *so* productive
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:41): phukq: We ship procmail on the Companion CD; I recommend it highly.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:42): wesolows: i read my mail on SuSE
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:42): procmail: because *no one* should have to read GPL vs. CDDL threads.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (05:42): I'm going to unsubscribe, I guess.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (05:42): I'd hoped all the signal would move before I did that.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:43): seriously now, opensolaris-discuss is quickly losing relevance because of all these recurring pointless threads

c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:43): richlowe: which list is giving trouble these days?  I saw the Joerg vs. Paul Jakma thread, but I'm guessing the ones you mention are on -discuss aka opensolaris-sewer
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:43): phukq: it never *had* any relevance
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:43): wesolows: you have a point
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:43): it's better to have a sewer than no sewer :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:44): 19th century London should teach you that.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:44): delewis: Yes, I agree that it serves a useful purpose.  But its name doesn't reflect that purpose.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:44): We ought not encourage anyone who wants to have a productive conversation about anything to use it.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:44): wesolows: true, but I'm sure if sewage had a mind of its own, it wouldn't want to be confined to a place called the sewer.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:45): It's for OT threads, flames, junk, spam, crap, job postings, and other undesirable garbage.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:45): ah, job postings.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:45): wesolows: you forgot star :-P
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:45): delewis: an interesting assertion.  Thankfully, we're not likely to find out. :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:45): there was one of those the other day.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:45): schilly-tools promotion :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:45): osol-endlessly-promote-tools-i-authored
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:45): delewis: of course; that's the marketing machine that never ends.  He should go work for Coca-Cola or Disney.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:46): opensolaris-discuss-me
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:46): star: because anything else would be "unusable"
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:46): wesolows: yup. i have no idea how did i survive until now just with plain ol' tar or gnu tar
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:46): well, it's ok; at least he writes code and contributes something.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:47): the Debian people would argue otherwise. :-)
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:47): that's because they're equally stubborn
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:47): then again, they argue with anything.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:47): exactly
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:48): I don't use star, but I'm sure people do and find it useful, and that's good enough to satisfy me that joerg is doing something good
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:48): not to mention cdrecord
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:48): so it's all fine
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:49): I use his software sometimes, and appreciate his work, and I junkbin any mail from him to a public mailing list.  Best of both worlds.

6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:49): wesolows: i have nothing against star, i am sure it is a wonderful piece of software. however, the more someone uses a cattleprod to entice me to use it, the less i am inclined to even try it. :-)
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:49): phukq: Indeed, there is that.  Another reason, perhaps, that I ignore his mail.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:50): phukq: But really I don't use star because other tars do what I want.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:50): and when they don't, it's because I really need cpio and not tar...
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:50): create an archive, extract files from an archive
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:50): wesolows: uhm ... like ... they "tar" ? :-P
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:50): what more do you need?
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:50): delewis: yeah, pretty much.  portability is a requirement, but that's about all.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:50): if I want to explicitly specify what files I want included in an archive, I'll use cpio.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:51): wesolows: I haven't had any problems with portability with the 'tar' in Solaris (other than mangling of GNU extensions)

c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:51): the one thing tar does that's bad is it overwrites files when extracting.  cpio renames the new files on top of existing ones, if any, which is why bfu uses it.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:51): delewis: nor have I
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:51): interesting.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:51): I don't know whether star does that
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:52): wesolows: i think Solaris tar doesn't understand -C
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:52): phukq: correct.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:52): (or maybe older versions)
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:52): undoubtedly there is some non-getopt-compliant option 8 characters long that controls them
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:52): and I will admit that -C is *kind* of nice.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:52): (cd ${_C_argument} && tar $*)
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:52): move along, nothing to see there
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:52): delewis: it's not as much as it's nice as there's all these GNUmakefiles which expect it and then  it doesn't work and then $#@_)(#$$&@#(!!!!!

c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:53): phukq: well, that's a different problem - the makefiles are broken; if they expect GNU tar, they need to make sure they're using GNU tar.  On most platforms, the safe thing to do is use 'gtar' instead.

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:53): I usually find the need for -C when I'm about half-way through typing out a command involving tar, and I think "Oh shit, I'm in the wrong directory". (this is especially "bad", when you're not using a shell with a editting features)
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:54): delewis: indeed, but once again this sounds like the gun is aimed at the messenger :-)
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (05:55): wesolows: shooting the messenger is an old, tried and true method of dealing with subtle problems :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:55): don't shoot the user. shoot the maintainer.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:55): the "new way" of feature requests.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:58): hmm, lint -Nlevel=4 seems to give spurious warnings.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:58): I guess that's to be expected.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:58): ahh, lint
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:59): a guaranteed false positive in every invocation!
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (05:59): my code is OK until -Nlevel=2, but towards 3 and 4, it hits the fan.
c35c800eed49fbcaa0bbf6ad7b2093eb (05:59): it's like gcc -Wall -Wextra and all the other -W options turned on.  The noise will hide whatever legitimate problems you have.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (06:00): hmm, I read an interesting article the other day about how SunOS 4.x and Solaris 2.x kernels were "lint-safe"
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (06:00): I wonder if that's still true and to what level are they safe.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (06:00): if so, that's an impressive accomplishment.
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (06:00): wesolows: Hey, you wrote the bit of the devref about not using LINTLIBRARY in kernel code, right?  I assume that's because they can hide legitimate warnings?
72bac19ca0a2ff15f99326a8f7e02c10 (06:01): /* LINTLIBRARY */, that is
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (06:02): impressive accomplishment not on any technical merits or sanity but on the sanity of the kernel engineers. :-)
